text: Client escalated due to missing evidence for milestone closure; arguments relied on assumptions rather than verified logs.
Escalation arose because no audit trail or screenshots substantiated the milestone sign-off; review was assumption-led.
Milestone validation lacked log extracts and test artifacts, prompting client escalation over evidence gaps.
Client questioned completion as the evidence pack was incomplete and largely narrative without data.
Review relied on subjective interpretation; no telemetry or validation dataset was provided, triggering escalation.
Client flagged the milestone as unproven because the evidence bundle lacked reproducible steps and raw results.
Escalation occurred when assertions replaced facts; no system logs or metrics corroborated the milestone claim.
Client disputed closure because validation evidence was anecdotal, with no attached results or run IDs to verify.
The review leaned on estimates instead of proof; missing execution logs led to an immediate client escalation.
Evidence confidence was low: no linked tickets, screenshots, or artifacts were shared to justify completion status.
Client challenged the milestone as speculative because validation relied on verbal summaries, not data-backed proofs.
Escalation risk materialized when acceptance criteria lacked traceable evidence and reproducible validations.
Assumption-driven claims without CI pipeline logs or test reports caused the client to escalate the review outcome.
Milestone evidence lacked hash-stamped artifacts and execution IDs, undermining confidence and triggering escalation.
Client cited poor documentation integrity; assertions were not matched with system-of-record data or audit trails.
Review panel found no cross-referenced logs to support milestone closure, leading to a formal escalation path.
Evidence pack did not include pass/fail matrices or run artifacts; client raised the issue to escalation management.
Assumptions replaced verification as no validation runs were attached; client disputed the milestone status.
The team presented conclusions without raw evidence, raising interpretation bias and causing client escalation.
No traceability from requirements to test results was shown; client formally escalated the acceptance decision.

No proof points or linked artifacts were shared; conclusions appeared biased, prompting a client escalation.
